headline: Flash Flooding in Pittsburgh
summary: A pair of storms pounded the city Friday, overwhelming the drainage system and causing manhole covers to pop off the road.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of Aug. 20-21, 2011

headline: Laptop Backpacks
summary: With an office-appropriate bag, you don't have to look like a freshman.

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Aug. 20, 2011

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Aug. 20, 2011

headline: Test Your Prediction Skills
summary: What's ahead for 15-year fixed-rate mortgages?

headline: Fighting Erupts in Tripoli
summary: Fierce street fights broke out in Tripoli, according to residents and rebel fighters, as rebels took to the streets and clashed with heavily armed government forces. Pictured: Libyans in Benghazi celebrate the reported Tripoli uprising.

headline: Plane Crash in Canadian Arctic Kills 12
summary: A Boeing 737-200 carrying 15 crashed Saturday afternoon near the town of Resolute in Canada's Arctic North, killing 12, Canadian authorities and air-industry officials said.

headline: Israel Faces Crises on Two Fronts
summary: Israel struggled with twin crises, as fallout from a militant strike on the Egyptian border two days ago spurred a deadly escalation with Hamas in the Gaza Strip and rattled diplomatic relations with Egypt.

headline: Libya's Oil Chief in Tunisia, Unlikely to Return
summary: The head of Libya's oil operations is in Tunisia and is unlikely to return to Tripoli, Libyan oil sources said Saturday.

headline: Dozens Arrested at Protest of Pipeline
summary: Dozens of people were arrested in front of the White House after staging a rally to protest a 1,700-mile oil pipeline that TransCanada Corp. wants to build from Canada to Texas.

headline: Verizon Employees to Return to Work
summary: About 45,000 Verizon Communications workers agreed to return to work Tuesday, while negotiations continue over deep benefits cuts the telecommunications giant is seeking.

headline: Madoff Case Against Mets Advances
summary: After listening to both sides argue about whether the case could go forward, the judge said that he would proceed on the assumption at least portions of the case team owners Fred Wilpon and Saul Katz and their business partners would remain intact.

headline: BofA Chief Makes Headway
summary: Bank of America CEO Moynihan has faced recent skepticism amid concerns about capital levels, but this week's move to trim staff and pare some operations suggest he is making progress on his pledge to cut costs and sharpen the bank's focus.

headline: S. Koreans Protest North's Prison Camps
summary: South Korean activists protested North Korea's use of concentration camps and called on Pyongyang to release South Koreans who are believed to be imprisoned in them.

headline: India Names Growth Targets
summary: Despite worsening global uncertainties and domestic inflationary pressures, India is aiming for 9% annual growth over a five-year period.

headline: Put Politics Aside, Obama Says
summary: Obama used his weekly radio address to the nation to urge Congress to put politics aside and pass a series of measures to jolt the economy.

headline: ETFs Won't Shake Hong Kong Markets, Official Says
summary: Beijing's plan to allow exchange-traded funds comprising Hong Kong-listed stocks to be sold to mainland investors wouldn't cause huge volatility in the city's equities market.

headline: The Best Portable Grills
summary: Our favorite portable grills, including models from Cuisinart, Weber, Cobb and Coleman.

headline: B&N Wins Financial Liberty
summary: The conclusion to Liberty Media's dance with Barnes & Noble may have disappointed some speculative investors hoping for a buyout. But those dumping the stock now are giving up on this tale too early.

headline: Radiation Detected in Rice in Japan
summary: A Japanese regional government said it had detected radioactive contamination in rice that was well below levels considered hazardous, amid continuing worries in Japan over food safety following the March 11 nuclear disaster.

headline: Target-Date Funds Are Looking Better
summary: They performed poorly in the 2008 meltdown, but some key target-date funds held up better during the market's recent plunge.

headline: Markets Stagger; Google Buys; H-P Pivots
summary: The week in essential news and analysis, graphics, photos and stats.

headline: How Volatility Eases Estate Planning
summary: Market volatility may be tough on the nerves, but it could be a boon for wealthy families looking to shelter assets from taxes.

headline: Week in Ideas: Highflying CEOs, Cannibalistic Brains
summary: Risk-taking private pilots make for effectively nervy CEOs; the dieting brain consumes itself; multiple choices lead to higher-quality selections; engineered bacteria sponge up mercury.

headline: Couples Has a Challenge for Woods
summary: U.S. Presidents Cup captain Fred Couples pulls rank on Tiger Woods. Plus, big names battle for FedEx Cup berths.

headline: Banks Fall in Europe; Seoul Slides
summary: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index fell 1.6% to end the week at 223.13. It dropped 6% over the five sessions. South Korea's market lost 6.2% on Friday.

headline: Guy Blue Heaven
summary: Ralph Lauren launches a new men's denim line under its dapper Black Label.

headline: Technology Can't Save Us From Math Mishaps
summary: A series of recent revisions involving high-stakes numbers shows that even computer software can't prevent mathematical mishaps.

headline: Parolee Arrested in Alleged Gun Plan
summary: A 72-year-old Staten Island man, who once served 18 years in prison for manslaughter after being convicted of killing his wife, pleaded not guilty to charges of attempting to buy a gun to kill a former girlfriend who allegedly owed him money.

headline: Jenkins: The Bailout Isn't Working
summary: Bank of America is the canary in the coal mine.

headline: Finding Inspiration in the Flesh
summary: A signature work by the Old Master painter, par excellence, of the unclothed human body.

headline: In Brief: Ready Player One
summary: Ernest Cline conjures a dystopic virtual playground for an underdog teenage hero in his new sci-fi thriller, "Ready Player One." Tom Shippey reviews.

headline: Surgery Adds New Twist to Osi Saga
summary: When Osi Umenyiora's knee was troubling him last week, his doctors said he'd need to practice on it for a few days before they could determine if he'd need surgery. So the Giants defensive end practiced on it three days this week—and then underwent surgery Friday.

headline: Icahn Seeks Ouster of Clorox's Board
summary: Carl Icahn said he intends to nominate 11 people, including himself, to replace Clorox's board at the household-products company's next shareholder meeting.

headline: Fast Five: Dark Drop Earrings
summary: For a cool contrast, wear these dark dangly earrings with the brightest of summer florals. Come fall, let them blend right into black cashmeres and gray flannels.

headline: Deal Frees 'West Memphis Three'
summary: Three men convicted of killing three 8-year-old Cub Scouts and dumping their bodies in a ditch have been allowed to change their pleas and were freed after nearly two decades in prison.

headline: Private Eye Forced to Disclose Who Told Him to Hack
summary: A U.K. court is forcing the private investigator at the center of the News Corp. phone-hacking scandal to disclose who told him to intercept voice mails.

headline: Death Toll in Indiana Collapse Rises to Six
summary: A 22-year-old college student died from injuries suffered when a stage collapsed into fans awaiting a concert by the country duo Sugarland at the Indiana State Fair.

headline: U.S. to Sell Gulf Drilling Leases
summary: The U.S. said it will sell leases for offshore drilling in the Gulf of Mexico for the first time since last year's oil spill.

headline: Photo-Op: Dark Light
summary: The photography of Josef Hoflehner explores the blisteringly bright seascapes and inscrutable shadows of Zanzibar.

headline: FrontPoint Hands Over Hedge Fund
summary: FrontPoint Partners, the hedge-fund firm rocked by an insider-trading case involving one of its former managers, continues to shrink as the firm plans to offload a credit fund to MatlinPatterson.

headline: H-P's PC Exit Puts Focus on Dell
summary: H-P's planned exit of the personal-computer business will leave Dell as the last big American PC maker.

headline: India and the 'Grammar of Anarchy'
summary: The antics of an anticorruption guru flout the constitution.

headline: Stocks End Week on a Sour Note
summary: U.S stocks tumbled Friday as investors continued worrying about a potential global recession and the health of the European banking system.

headline: Your Co-Workers Might Be Killing You
summary: Workplace stress is one of the key factors in how long you'll live. Jonah Lehrer looks at a new study with some surprising findings on different health outcomes for women and men.

headline: Stocks Sink
summary: What happened to your money this week.

headline: 'Mad' Woman Janie Bryant
summary: The costume designer for "Mad Men" on her new collaboration with Banana Republic, her dislike of '90s fashion and the secret to Don Draper's sex appeal.

headline: St. Petersburg Voters Go to Polls in a 'Secret' Election
summary: Opposition politicians allege that the country's ruling party organized local elections in secret, including arranging for political unknowns to share a ballot with the governor, a longtime Kremlin ally.

headline: For Bargain Stocks, Check Patent Office
summary: Anyone can spot a low price/earnings ratio. But figuring out which companies hold undervalued patents can give you a real edge.

headline: Actor Channels His Artsy Side
summary: Ryan Gosling gives multi-hyphenated actor James Franco some competition.

headline: Week in Words
summary: A field guide to unusual words in this week's Wall Street Journal: bines, oast, Lollywood, obon and guilloche.

headline: The Artists Who Made a Poster a Day
summary: From 1941 to 1945, artists working for the Telegraph Agency of the Soviet Union produced hundreds of posters in an effort to keep Soviet citizens reassured. These posters form the core of "Windows on the War," a show of Soviet propaganda at the Art Institute of Chicago.

headline: The People's Works of Art
summary: Lance Esplund reviews the BMW Guggenheim Lab in the East Village and the New Museum's 'Ostalgia' exhibit of artists from across Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Republics.

headline: Long Summer for 'Weary Tiger' Mothers
summary: Seventies parenting bore a resemblance to crate training—now, we're actually expected to watch our kids. Samantha Bee on the countdown to fall.

headline: Berlin Faces Car Burning Surge
summary: German authorities are scrambling to contain and make sense of a surge in car torchings in the nation's capital that have raised fears that the vandalism spree could escalate.

headline: Fans Seek to Preserve Ranch Houses
summary: With a growing number of ranch homes turning 50 years old—the age at which the U.S. Department of the Interior says most buildings may be considered for the National Register of Historic Places—efforts are under way to protect them.

headline: Mayor's Soda Plan Fails
summary: The Obama administration has rejected Mayor Michael Bloomberg's request to bar New York City's food stamp recipients from using their benefits to buy soda and other sugary drinks, a defeat for a mayor who is struggling to produce significant new policy accomplishments in his third term.

headline: Tethered Ships Are Really Structures
summary: The controversy addressed by Anthony Paletta's article(Cross Country, Aug. 6) is just the tip of the proverbial iceberg. Throughout the U.S. there are land-use abuses being perpetrated by profitable cruise ship line.

headline: Best-Selling Books, Week Ended Aug. 14
summary: With data from Nielsen BookScan.

headline: Here Comes the Dress
summary: Images from "The Wedding Dress" a new book that looks at 300 years of bridal fashion.

headline: Claes Oldenburg On Thinking Big
summary: On Saturday, the Pop sculptor will begin installing his "Paint Torch," a 51-foot-high rendition of a paintbrush, in Philadelphia. Here, he talks about the sculpture, his artistic beginnings and what it's like to work on his own.

headline: Proposed SEC Rule on Share Buying Faces Opposition
summary: A diverse group of investors are lobbying against a proposed change in a federal rule that would speed up the time frame for alerting the public to the amassing of shares in a company.

headline: Bearing Gifts to the Needy Greeks
summary: If it wasn't for the Greeks, Joe Queenan notes, we wouldn't have "Oedipus Rex" or Plato's "Republic" or all those neoclassical buildings in Washington or those brilliant theories by Aristotle. So we owe them.

headline: Farro Tagliatelle
summary: For her second Slow Food Fast recipe, Alice Waters of Chez Panisse cooks up whole-wheat pasta with a light yet juicy tomato sauce.

headline: Long Bonds Push Higher
summary: The 30-year bond proved again it is the sweetest spot in the safe-haven Treasury market, while shorter-dated notes took a breather.

headline: Did Mom Fix Jones's Swing?

headline: Joy Meets Rebels in Libya Town
summary: Rebel advances in Gharyan and in the coastal town of Zawiya have severed road links and supply lines to and from the capital.

headline: Hewlett the Cash Out?
summary: Tech investors better get serious about watching the piggybank. The two big deals of the past week demonstrate loud and clear the risk that companies could blow their cash piles, hammering the value of their stock.

headline: The Frisbee Upgrade
summary: Lightweight, soft to the touch and easy to throw, this new flying disc will make you rediscover the quintessential summer game.

headline: Husband Is Charged in N.J. Ambush
summary: The husband of a 27-year-old mother who was ambushed and fatally shot while walking in a New Jersey suburb was charged Friday with her murder, authorities said.

headline: Penney Gives Ackman Leeway
summary: J.C. Penney and its largest shareholder have agreed to cap his shareholdings in the retailer at 16.5%, while still allowing him to expand his financial interest in the company.

headline: Reversing the Decay Behind London Undone
summary: Britain's chief rabbi on the moral disintegration since the 1960s and how to rebuild.

headline: California Courts Face Cash Crunch
summary: Three years of budget cuts have translated into longer waits for everything from fighting traffic tickets to getting family-court matters resolved—and things are likely to get worse.

headline: Staying Crisp in Summer
summary: August is a good time to visit PicNic Market and Cafe, an Alsatian bistro on the northern end of the Upper West Side. In the summer, the restaurant sources at least 50% of its produce from Bradley Farms in New Paltz.

headline: Jets Rookie Begins Career With a Beating
summary: As if the beating he took in Monday night's preseason opener wasn't enough, the hits kept coming for New York Jets rookie quarterback Greg McElroy when the team returned to practice. Of the nearly 50 times he dropped back to throw in the opener, he was sacked five times and hit a total of 14 times.

headline: Donna Karan: My Latest Bali High
summary: Designer Donna Karan recounts a recent vacation to Como Shambhala in Bali, a remote and luxurious resort that she calls her second home.

headline: H-Pain
summary: None

headline: Tight End Spot Remains in Flux
summary: Converted halfback Travis Beckum is the front-runner to be the Giants' tight end, despite being undersized.

summary: Summer's almost over—have some fun! Try a wild jacket with subdued slacks or full-tilt crazy pants.

summary: U.S. and Europe markets sank Friday as worries deepened about the vulnerability of banks to a possible recession and their exposure to shaky countries.

summary: Municipal officials in the Mediterranean resort of Saint-Tropez are in a cold sweat: The rush into the Swiss franc is creating a time bomb for city finances.

headline: Hazare Styled Life of Activism After Gandhi
summary: Anna Hazare, who has galvanized thousands of Indians to protest against corruption, has spent most of his life in social activism, following a legendary escape from a Pakistani air raid.

headline: A Rush to Pipe Oil to Gulf
summary: The race is on to build pipelines to relieve a glut of crude oil in the U.S. heartland, but not all of the four plans will make it to the finish line.

headline: Rove Shouldn't Count His Chickens Just Yet
summary: Contrary to what Karl Rove writes, the cost of entitlements does not contribute to our fiscal problems ("Obama's No Good, Very Bad Week," op-ed, Aug. 11).

headline: What to Do With Your Rising-Rate Bets
summary: Rising rates looked like such a sure thing back in April. Not anymore. Here's what investors should do with their floating-rate funds and other positions they bought earlier this year.

headline: A Truce in the War Over Smarts and Genes

headline: President Obama Is the Same Now as He Was in the Past
summary: In "What Happened to Obama? Absolutely Nothing" (op-ed, Aug. 13) Norman Podhoretz observes that Mr. Obama "is still the same anti-American leftist he was before becoming our president."

headline: Cooking With Basil and Its Friends
summary: Pair basil with everything from salmon to strawberries—this pretty herb brings out the best in every dish it meets.

headline: An Inferior Tax Cut

headline: Smoke Show
summary: Bill Paley, son of Babe and Will, revives his grandfather's cigar company, La Palina.

summary: From black bean soup to Cuban-style paella, "The Cuban Kitchen" offers a comprehensive guide to a cuisine inspired by Spanish, African and Arabian traditions.

headline: Port Authority Raises Fees, Delays Plans
summary: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said it is again delaying $5 billion of projects because an increase in fares and tolls approved on Friday was less than it originally had proposed.

headline: Investors Rebel Against H-P Plan
summary: Investors abandoned Hewlett-Packard after its plan to get out of the personal-computer business left serious questions about the technology company's strategy. Shares dropped 20%.

headline: A Tiny Ambassador to Entrancing Worlds
summary: A charming trio of knights sallies forth to battle monsters, a pink elephant grows up and learns to like asparagus, and September 11 is revisited in sobering, apolitical tones. Meghan Cox Gurdon reviews the newest offerings in children's literature.

headline: FAA Issues Ethics Rule for Inspectors
summary: The Federal Aviation Administration issued an ethics rule requiring safety inspectors and managers to wait two years after leaving the agency before taking certain jobs at any airline they previously oversaw.

headline: Yes, It's Still a Drugstore, Too
summary: If there's any institution that embodies the difference between the old New York and the new New York, forget Times Square and Bryant Park. Consider, instead, Duane Reade, the local drugstore chain that once turned buying a bottle of Pepto into an exercise in urban combat.

headline: Shell Stops North Sea Pipe Leak
summary: Royal Dutch Shell said it has stopped a leak from an underwater pipe at a North Sea platform that has been spilling crude oil for more than a week.

summary: U.S. regulators on Friday closed a bank in Florida and Georgia, pushing this year's tally of bank failures to 67.

headline: Some Projects Need a Long Gestation
summary: I share the expressed concerns regarding infrastructure delays caused by so many intrusive regulations, unless the proposed project were to be in my backyard (Yes to Infrastructure, but No to More Federal Programs," Letters, Aug. 17).

headline: EU Prepares Syria Oil Embargo
summary: The European Union is set to move ahead with an oil embargo on Syria but is likely to leave a possible ban on European investment in the Syrian energy sector for a future round of measures, EU diplomats said on Monday.

headline: Squash Blossoms: Flowers to Savor
summary: Whether sautéed, stuffed, baked or fried, squash blossoms are one of summer's showiest pleasures.

headline: Zimbabwe Firms Told to Yield Control
summary: Multinationals in Zimbabwe have two weeks to submit new plans for handing over majority control in local operations to black locals, stirring fresh resistance to a corporate "indigenization" campaign.

headline: Folding Flats for Travel
summary: With super-slim profiles and bendable soles, these shoes will fit in the most crammed luggage, and still look good your toes.

headline: School Improvement Awaits More Than Super Teachers
summary: The essay "Super Teachers Alone Can't Save Our Schools," (Review, Aug. 13) fails to identify the obvious remedy to the main cause of teacher burnout. Student to teacher ratios must be shrunk immediately.

headline: Robert Costa: Scott Walker Claims Victory in the Battle of Wisconsin
summary: President Obama, the governor notes, avoided the state on his recent trip to the Midwest.

headline: The Full Monticello
summary: Former White House design consultant Carleton Varney uncovers clever design ideas in Monticello's zingy yellow dining room.

headline: Getting Artsy-Cartsy
summary: At the 'Big Apple Bash' to support the Museum of the City of New York, guests took a gander at 'Moveable Feast,' a clever and absorbing exhibit about food carts and 'green carts' in the city.

headline: Indian Activist Begins Delhi Protest
summary: Indian activist Anna Hazare led a large procession of supporters through the city's streets before launching a hunger fast and demonstration designed to pressure the government to enact strong anti-corruption reforms.

headline: Major Minor
summary: Joseph Heller, the author of "Catch-22," was a first-class second-rate writer, says Alec Solomita.

headline: Uncle Sam's Techtonic Shift
summary: Slower government sales hit NetApp, other tech firms. But is it due to the debt-ceiling talks or something more severe?

headline: Five Best: Dispatches From the Natural World
summary: Poet and novelist Brad Leithauser on Thoreau's "Walden," Gordon Grice's "Deadly Kingdom" and other illuminating books about the great outdoors.

headline: Hughes, Martin Star As Yankees Beat Twins
summary: On only the second batter of Friday's game, New York's Phil Hughes grooved a fastball, and Minnesota's Trevor Plouffe hit it out of the park to give the Twins a 1-0 lead.

headline: Dollar Reaches New Low vs. Yen
summary: Despite the near constant risk of intervention, traders continued to make bets in favor of the yen, sending the dollar to a record low against the Japanese currency.

headline: Saying Goodbye to Pinot Noir—for a While
summary: Pinot Noir is great, but its popularity has led to rampant overpricing. Lettie Teague takes a break from the grape and finds some great alternatives, from Gamay to Nebbiolo to the obscure Fer Servadou.

headline: His Wealth of Nations
summary: The story of how New World riches fueled Old World wars. Brendan Simms reviews "The Golden Empire."

headline: Violence Escalates on Israeli Border
summary: Israel's army killed seven Palestinians while militants fired two dozen rockets into southern Israel from the Gaza Strip, in an escalation of violence triggered by a chain of attacks that began with the killing of eight Israelis.

headline: Rift on Terms Threatens Greece Aid
summary: Europe's latest bailout for Greece is in danger of fraying over whether countries giving Greece aid should receive cash collateral.

headline: Turning Losses Into Tax Gains
summary: The sharp market plunges of recent weeks have at least one benefit: the change to harvest your tax losses.

headline: Where Sisters Splash Down
summary: Along a certain stretch of the Jersey Shore, T-shirts seen advertising Nuns' Beach seem to be just another bit of satirical beachwear. But the beach in question is very real, as are the nuns who have flocked to the popular surfing spot for the last 75 years.

headline: A True Insider at 'Book of Mormon'
summary: An actor brings a unique perspective to the Tony-winning musical: He was a member of the Church of Latter Day Saints.

headline: Burger King Mascot Retires
summary: Burger's King's "the King" mascot is retiring so the struggling burger chain can refocus its marketing to reach new customers.

headline: Roads Bill Gets Another Look
summary: The White House and congressional Democrats are working on a plan to jump-start passage of a stalled highway bill as the administration reworks part of its strategy for responding to high unemployment.

headline: Jobless Rate Rises in Most States
summary: Jobless rates increased in most states last month. Twenty-eight states and the District of Columbia logged increases in their unemployment rates in July.

headline: Soft Economy Lingers in Martha's Vineyard
summary: During his nine-day visit to Martha's Vineyard, President Obama will find an economy still trying to find its footing.

headline: Helping Backpacks
summary: To help get the school year off to a good start, the High Water Women Foundation is giving thousands of students a brand-new backpack stuffed with school supplies.

headline: Keeping It in the Family
summary: One of the more exciting things about the opening of Lola Schnabel's "Iodine Portraits" at the Tripoli Gallery here was that for those not interested in an alcoholic beverage, there were fresh coconuts with straws in them to drink.

headline: Novelist-Scientists Versus Novelist-Mystics
summary: The novelist Alex Shakar explores the two camps of his profession: The scientist types who insist on planning every book in close detail and the mystics who aver that stories must blossom organically. The truth lies between the poles.

headline: 'Follies' Costume Drama
summary: The Broadway revival of Stephen Sondheim's 'Follies' gave costume designer Gregg Barnes a number of challenges.

headline: EU to Boost Syria Sanctions Where It Hurts Most: Oil Exports
summary: The European Union agreed on Friday to broaden sanctions on Syria's regime and penalize its backers, advancing an international effort to target the regime's finances, as security forces continued to crack down on protesters.

headline: Memorializing a Painful Chapter of History
summary: Japanese-Americans returned to rural Wyoming this week for the opening of a museum at the site of a World War II internment camp.

headline: Beijing Voices Faith in U.S. Economy
summary: China's economy will not suffer from a "hard landing," Vice President Xi Jinping said in meetings with Joe Biden, whose trip to China is aimed in large part at reassuring China the U.S. fiscal situation is sound.

headline: Portrait of the Angry Investor
summary: The mood of investors is at least as bad as in the darkest days of early 2009, when the financial world itself seemed about to end. What does this mean for the markets?

headline: Former Rangers Captain Drury Retires
summary: Former Rangers captain Chris Drury retired on Friday to bring an end to a 12-year NHL career that included 615 points but also a sizable contract with the Rangers that made him a target for criticism.
